revision.text:
{{More footnotes|date=September 2010}} {{Main|Companion planting}} {{dynamic list}} This is a '''list of [[companion planting|companion plants]]'''. Many more are in the [[list of beneficial weeds]]. Companion plants assist in the growth of others by attracting [[beneficial insects]], [[List of pest-repelling plants|repelling pests]], or providing nutrients, shade, or support. They can be part of a [[biological pest control]] program.
==Vegetables==
{| style="border: 4px outset #ffafaf;background:#ffbfbf" cellpadding="2px" cellspacing="0" |- ! colspan=8 style="background-color:#ff9f9f;font-size:160%;" | Vegetables |- style="background:#ff9f9f" ! Common name !! Scientific name !! Helps !! Helped by !! Attracts !! -Repels/+distracts !! Avoid !! Comments |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Allium]]s''' || ''Allium'' || Fruit trees,<ref name=whatAroundFruitTrees /> [[nightshade]]s (tomatoes,<ref name="tomato-garlic">{{cite journal |url=http://www.aensiweb.net/AENSIWEB/rjabs/rjabs/2012/256-260.pdf |title=Evaluation of yield and its components of intercropped tomato – garlic in New Valley Governorate |last=Nassef |first=Dalia |last2=El-Gaid |first2=M.A. Abd |journal=Research Journal of Agriculture and Biological Sciences |year=2012 |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=256–260}}</ref> capsicum peppers,<ref name="field production of peppers">{{cite journal | url=http://horttech.ashspublications.org/content/20/3/530.full.pdf+html |title=Intercropping for field production of peppers |journal=HortTechnology |date=June 2010 |last=Kahn |first=Brian A. |volume=20 |issue=3 |pages=530–532}}</ref> potatoes<ref name="Allium-potato">{{cite journal |title=The influence of intercropping with Allium on some insect populations in potato (Solatium tuberosum) |last=Potts |first=Michael J. |last2=Gunadi |first2=Nikardi |journal=Annals of Applied Biology |year=1991 |volume=119 |issue=1 |pages=207–213 |doi=10.1111/j.1744-7348.1991.tb04859.x}}</ref>), brassicas,<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_3 /> carrots<ref name=sfgateOnionsAndGarlic /><ref name="carrots-onions" /> || Carrots,<ref name="carrots-onions">{{cite journal |url=http://www.actahort.org/books/579/579_88.htm |title=Effect of intercropping on the population density of pests in some vegetables |last=Mateeva |first=A. |last2=Ivanova |first2=M. |last3=Vassileva |first3=M. |year=2002 |journal=Acta Horticulturae |volume=579 |pages=507–511}}</ref> tomatoes,<ref>[http://agris.fao.org/ag.ris-search/search.do?recordID=SD2010000059 Intercropping: A participatory ipm-model for small scale vegetable farmers in Southern Blue Nile Region, Sudan]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> carrots and African spider plants (''[[Cleome gynandra]]'') together, marigolds (''Tagetes'' spp.),<ref name="finch-field-crops">{{cite journal |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1570-7458.2011.01191.x/pdf |title=The influence of host and non-host companion plants on the behaviour of pest insects in field crops |last=Finch |first=S. |last2=Collier |first2=Rosemary H. |journal=Entomologia Experimentalis et Applicata |year=2012 |volume=142 |issue=2 |pages=87–96 |doi=10.1111/j.1570-7458.2011.01191.x}}</ref><ref name="InTech" /> mints<ref name="finch-field-crops" /><ref name="InTech" /> || Thrips || -rabbits,<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_3>{{cite Beans provide the nitrogen carrots need more than some other vegetables. Aromatic companion plants repel [[carrot fly]]. Sage, rosemary, and radishes are recommended by ''some'' as companion plants, but listed by others as incompatible. Alliums inter-planted with carrots confuse onion and carrot flies. For the beneficial insect-attracting properties of carrots to work, they need to be allowed to flower; Otherwise, use the wild carrot, Queen Anne's Lace, for the same effect. Flax produces an oil that may protect root vegetables like carrots from some pests. |- | '''[[Cauliflower]]''' || ''Brassica oleracea'' || Beans,<ref name="carrotsLoveTomatoes_2" /> celery,<ref name="carrotsLoveTomatoes_3" /> spinach,<ref name="cauliflower and spinach">{{cite journal |url=http://tjeas.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/135-140.pdf |title=Investigation of intercropping cauliflower and spinach in north of Iran |journal=Technical Journal of Engineering and Applied Sciences |last=Amoli |first=Nahid |year=2012 |volume=2 |issue=6 |pages=135–140}}</ref> peas<ref name="pea intercropping" /> || Mixture of Chinese cabbage, marigolds, rape, and sunflower.<ref name="InTech" /> Spinach,<ref name="cauliflower and spinach" /> peas<ref name="pea intercropping" /> || || || || One row of spinach alternating at 60 cm from each row of cauliflower proved mutually beneficial.<ref name="cauliflower and spinach" /> See brassicas for more info. predatory insects to the garden, they are particularly helpful when left under fruit trees, the predators attacking codling moth and light brown apple moth. Issaas |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=95–103}}</ref> || || || Cutworms || || Has been shown to reduce cutworms in eggplant in laboratory trials but needs field testing |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Lovage]]''' || ''Levisticum officinale'' || Beans<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> || || Ichneumonid wasps, ground beetles (good) || || Rhubarb || Is thought to improve the health of almost all plants, like borage and geraniums, is considered a "magic bullet" of companion planting |- | '''[[Oregano]]''' || ''Origanum vulgare'' || Grapes, tomatoes, peppers, pumpkin,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> many other plants|| Basil || Hoverflies/Syrphidae<ref name="flower flies" /> || Aphids<ref name="flower flies" /> || || Provides ground cover and much-needed humidity for pepper plants if allowed to spread among them. Because it attracts syrphidae, it reduces aphids through predation.<ref name="flower flies" /> |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Parsley]]''' || ''Petroselinum crispum'' || Asparagus,<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_1 /><ref name="utahpests" /> corn/maize, tomatoes || Apple, asparagus,<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_1 /><ref name="utahpests" /> rose || Swallowtail butterflies, wasps, flies || || Alliums, lettuce || Sacrificially attracts insects that feed on tomatoes |- | '''[[Peppermint]]''' || ''Mentha piperita'' || Alliums,<ref name="finch-field-crops" /><ref name="InTech" /> brassicas,<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_3 /><ref name="finch-field-crops" /><ref name="InTech" /> cabbage,<ref name="InTech" /><ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /><ref name="limestone" /> peas,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> tomatoes<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> || || || Cabbage root fly,<ref name="finch-field-crops" /> ants,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cabbage looper, aphids,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> onion fly<ref name="finch-field-crops" /> || || Repels cabbage flies, has same general companion properties as other mints |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Rosemary]]''' || ''Rosmarinus officinalis'' || Cabbage,<ref name="limestone" /> beans,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /><ref name="limestone" /><ref name="Cornell bean" /> brassicas,<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_3 /><ref name="InTech" /> carrots,<ref name=cornellCompanionPlanting /> thyme || || || Bean beetle || || Deters cabbage flies, repels many bean parasites |- ! '''[[Tarragon]]''' || ''Artemisia dracunculus'' || Most vegetables,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> but especially eggplant || || || || || Its scent is disliked by most pests, and this plant is also thought to have Nurse Plant properties, enhancing the growth and flavor of crops grown with it. |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Thyme]]''' || ''Thymus vulgaris'' || Brassicas,<ref | '''[[Yarrow]]''' || ''Achillea millefolium'' || Many plants, "Most aromatic plants."<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> || || Predatory wasps, ladybugs, hoverflies,<ref name="flower flies" /> '''[[Delphinium|Larkspur]]''' || ''Delphinium'' spp. || Beans,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cabbage<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> || || || || | |- | '''[[Lupin]]''' || ''Lupinus'' || Cucurbits, brassica, lettuce, rosemary, dill, strawberry,<ref name=strawberryCompanions /> rose || Summer savory, rose || Honeybees || || Tomatoes and other solanaceae || This wildflower is a legume, hosting bacteria that fixes nitrogen in the soil, fertilizing it for neighboring plants. Same with marigold, planting nearby roses causes them to grow vigorously. |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Tagetes|Marigold]]''' || ''[[Tagetes patula]], [[Tagetes erecta|T. erecta]], [[Tagetes minuta|T. minuta]]'' || Most plants, especially tomatoes<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> and peppers, cucurbits (cucumbers, gourds, squash, potatoes,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> roses,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> alliums,<ref name="finch-field-crops" /><ref name="InTech" /> brassicas,<ref name="finch-field-crops" /><ref name="InTech" /><ref name="flea beetle" /> zucchini<ref name="iastate" /> || Rose || Snails and slugs.<ref name="UCal Snails" /> || Root-knot nematodes,<ref name="UCal Nematodes">{{cite techreport |url=http://ucipm.ucdavis.edu/PDF/PESTNOTES/pnnematodes.pdf |title=Nematodes |number=Pest Notes 7489 |date=July 2010 |institution=University of California Statewide Integrated Pest Management Program}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncagr.gov/agronomi/pdffiles/nnote1.pdf|title=Root-knot Nematodes: Biocontrol with Marigolds}}</ref> [[beet leaf hopper]]s, cucumber beetle,<ref name="iastate" /> squash bug,<ref name="iastate" /> onion fly,<ref name="finch-field-crops" /> cabbage root fly<ref name="finch-field-crops" /> || || Marigolds are a wonder-drug of the companion plant world, invoking the saying "plant them everywhere in your garden". French marigolds ([[Tagetes patula|T. patula]]) produce a pesticidal chemical from their roots, so strong it lasts years after they are gone. Mexican marigolds ([[Tagetes erecta|T. erecta]]) do the same, but are so strong they will inhibit the growth of some more tender herbs. Stinking Roger ([[Tagetes minuta|T. minuta]]) has also been found effective against certain perennial weeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Tagetes+minuta|title=Tagetes minuta Muster-John-Henry PFAF Plant Database}}</ref> Same with lupin, planting nearby roses causes them to grow vigorously. |- ||'''[[Tropaeolum|Nasturtium]]''' || ''[[Tropaeolum majus]]'' || Beans, squash,<ref name=cornellCompanionPlanting /><ref name="garden bugs" /> tomatoes, fruit trees, brassicas,<ref name="InTech" /><ref name="iastate" /> radish<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /><ref name="limestone" /> cucumbers<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> || || Predatory insects || Aphids,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> asparagus beetle,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cabbage looper,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /><ref name="iastate" /> cabbage worm,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /><ref name="iastate" /> carrot fly,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cabbage weevil,<ref name="iastate" /> Colorado potato beetle<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> squash bug,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /><ref name="iastate" /> Japanese beetle,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> Mexican bean beetle,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> striped pumpkin beetles, whitefly,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cucumber beetles<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> flea beetle<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> || Cauliflower || Trap crops for aphids, is among the best at attracting predatory insects, deters many pests of cucurbits |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Pansy]]''' || ''Viola x wittrockiana'' || Alliums, onions, roses || Roses || || Bees, butterflies, ants || Ants (with aphids), snails, slugs, white butterfly || A good and nice-smelling flower that really attracts ants. It is like the viola plant, but has two or three colors in flowers. Helps alliums and onions, which repels the white butterfly. |- | '''[[Petunia]]''' || ''Petunia x hybrida'' || Cucurbits (squash, pumpkins, cucumbers), asparagus || || || Leafhoppers, Japanese beetles, aphids, asparagus beetle || || Is a trap crop almost identical to geraniums in function |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Phacelia]]''' || ''Phacelia tanacetifolia'' || Plants which are prone to aphids, especially lettuce, tomato, rose || || hoverfly || || || This plant attracts [[hoverfly|hoverflies]] and is good around plants which are prone to aphids.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lovely Companion Plant for Your Vegetable Garden: Phacelia|url=http://www.thelovelyplants.com/lovely-companion-plant-for-your-vegetable-garden-phacelia/}}</ref> |- | '''[[Rose]]''' || ''Rosa'' spp. || || Chives,<ref name=cornellCompanionPlanting /><ref name="limestone" /> garlic,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> marigolds<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> || || || || |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Sunflower]]''' || ''Helianthus annuus'' || Peppers,<ref name="sunflower-pepper" /><ref name="sunflower-trap" /> corn, cucumber,<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_4 /> soybeans,<ref name="soybean-corn-sunflower" /> tomatoes, [[Gomphocarpus physocarpus|swan plant]] || Swan plant|| || Aphids || Pole beans<ref name=carrotsLoveTomatoes_2 /> || Was grown as a companion for corn (maize) before modern Europeans arrived in the Americas, supposedly increases their production, ants herd aphids onto sunflowers, keeping them off neighboring plants. Works as a trap plant for thrips keeping them off of bell peppers.<ref name="sunflower-trap" /> Planting near swan plants help sunflowers grow rapidly. |- style="background:#9fffb3" ! Common name !! Scientific name !! Helps !! Helped by !! Attracts !! -Repels/+distracts !! Avoid !! Comments |- | '''[[Swan plant]]''' || ''Gomphocarpus physocarpus'', ''Asclepias physocarpa'', milkweed || Sunflower || Sunflower, basil || Monarch butterfly || Aphids || Plants that attracts [[aphids]] and [[spider mites]] || Attracts the [[monarch butterfly]] during spring and summer. Basil repels pests that attracts by the swan plant like aphids. |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Sweet pea]]''' || ''Lathyrus odoratus'' || || Brassica, spinach, silverbeet and salads || Bees || || Aphids || An [[annual plant|annual]] climbing plant, which is like the edible pea. Makes a good decoration in your garden or fence. |- | '''[[Tansy]]''' || ''Tanacetum vulgare'' || Beans, brassicas,<ref name="InTech" /> cucurbits (cucumbers, squash, etc.), raspberries and relatives, roses, corn, fruit trees<ref name=whatAroundFruitTrees /> || || Ladybugs, honeybees || flying insects(Ichneumonid wasps), ants,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> Japanese beetles,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cabbage butterfly,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cabbage maggot,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> asparagus beetle,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> carrot fly,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> striped cucumber beetles,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> Colorado potato beetle,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> cutworm,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> flea beetle,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> flies,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> imported cabbageworm,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> squash bugs,<ref name="cornellCompanionPlanting" /> [[mice]]|| || Toxic to people and many animals, don't plant it where livestock browse. Is reputed to generally repel insects (except for nectar-eating types). |- style="background:#ffffff" | '''[[Zinnia]]''' || ''Zinnia'' || Beans, tomatoes, peppers|| || || Whiteflies|| || Attracts hummingbirds that eat whiteflies, attracts pollinators |}

Also breaks up hardpan and other tough soil. Alfalfa has demonstrated some allelopathic effects to tomato seedlings<ref name="tomato-alfalfa" /> |- ||'''[[Peanut]]''' || ''Arachis hypogaea'' || Beans, corn, cucumber, eggplant, lettuce, marigold, melon and sunflower|| || || || || Peanuts encourage growth of corn and squash<ref name="Companion Planting"/> |- style="background:#ffffff" ||'''[[Walnut tree]]''' || [[Juglans|''Juglans'' spp.]] || Many types of grass including Kentucky bluegrass (''Poa pratensis''). || [[European alder]] (sacrifice plant), hairy vetch,<ref name=walnut-legumes-grasses>{{cite web|title=Site-improving intercrops for Black Walnut|url=http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/jrnl/1988/nc_1988_vansambeek_001.pdf?|work=Walnut Council Bulletin|accessdate=13 April 2014}}</ref> crownvetch,<ref name=walnut-legumes-grasses /> sericea lespedeza<ref name=walnut-legumes-grasses /> || || || Apple trees,<ref name=fruitTreeCompanions /> grasses<ref name=walnut-legumes-grasses /> || Black walnut is harmful to the growth of all [[nightshade]] plants, including ''[[Datura]]'' or Jimson weed, [[eggplant]], [[Mandragora officinarum|mandrake]], [[deadly nightshade]] or belladonna, [[capsicum]] ([[paprika]], [[chile pepper]]), [[potato]], [[tomato]], and [[petunia]]. |}

page.title: List of countries in Asia and Oceania by Human Development Index
List of ethnic groups in Ethiopia

revision.comment: /* References */ ethnic group of southern nationalities in Ethiopia and Northern Kenya
revision.text:
This is a '''list of ethnic groups in [[Ethiopia]]''' that are officially recognized by the [[Government of Ethiopia|government]]. It is a list taken from the 2007 Ethiopian National Census:[http://www.csa.gov.et/pdf/Cen2007_firstdraft.pdf 2007 Ethiopian census, first draft] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214000000/http://www.csa.gov.et/pdf/Cen2007_firstdraft.pdf |date=2012-02-14 }}, Ethiopian Central Statistical Agency (accessed 6 May 2009) Population size and percentage of Ethiopia's total population according to the 1994 and 2007 censuses follows each entry. Ethiopia's population is highly diverse, containing over 80 different ethnic groups. Most people in Ethiopia speak [[Afro-Asiatic languages]], mainly of the [[Cushitic languages|Cushitic]] and [[Semitic languages|Semitic]] branches. The former includes the [[Oromo people|Oromo]] and [[Somali people|Somali]], and the latter includes the [[Amhara people|Amhara]] and [[Tigrinya people|Tigray]]. Together these four groups make up three-quarters of the population. The country also has [[Omo people|Omotic]] ethnic minorities who speak [[Afro-Asiatic languages]] of the [[Omotic languages|Omotic]] branch. They inhabit the southern regions of the country, particularly the [[Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples' Region]]. Among these are the [[Welayta people|Welayta]] and [[Gamo people|Gamo]]. [[Nilo-Saharan languages|Nilo-Saharan]]-speaking [[Nilotic]] ethnic minorities also inhabit the southwestern regions of the country, particularly in the [[Gambela Region]]. Among these are the [[Nuer people|Nuer]] and [[Anuak people|Anuak]] who are also found in [[South Sudan]] which borders the Gambela Region. ==Officially recognized ethnic groups in Ethiopia== {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: right;" |+ |-bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! rowspan="2" | Ethnic

This is a list of famous people who have lived in [[Tbilisi]], including both natives and residents. Some figures in the list may be included in several of the categories simultaneously, but are only included in the sections which pertain to their achievements or occupations the most.
==Politicians, governmental figures and activists== * [[Irakli Bagration-Mukhraneli]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] prince, exiled to [[Spain]] * [[Kakha Bendukidze]], Georgian businessman * [[Lavrenti Beria]], head of the [[NKVD]] (the predecessor to the [[KGB]]), supervisor and one of the initiators of the [[Soviet Union]]'s Nuclear Project * [[Giga Bokeria]], Georgian political leader * [[Ilia Chavchavadze]], writer, politician, public benefactor * [[Gela Charkviani]], politician, current [[Ambassador]] of Georgia in the [[UK]] * [[Kakutsa Cholokashvili]], national hero of Georgia * [[Zviad Gamsakhurdia]], former [[president]] of Georgia * [[Alexander Griboedov]], diplomat, playwright, composer * [[Lev Kamenev]], [[Bolshevik]] revolutionary * [[Merab Kostava]], national hero and anti-Soviet activist * [[Aram Manukian]], [[Armenia]]n revolutionary, politician and general *[[Vsevolod Nikolayevich Merkulov]], former head of [[NKGB]] * [[Nariman Narimanov]], [[Azerbaijan]]i revolutionary, writer, politician * [[Yevgeny Primakov]], politician * [[Grand Duke Alexander Mikhailovich of Russia|Grand Duke Alexander Mikhailovich (Romanov) of Russia]] * [[Grand Duke George Mikhailovich of Russia (1863-1919)|Grand Duke George Mikhailovich (Romanov) of Russia]], first cousin of [[Alexander II of Russia|Emperor Alexander II of Russia]] * [[Grand Duke Michael Nicolaevich of Russia|Grand Duke Michael Nicolaevich (Romanov) of Russia]], son of [[Nicholas I of Russia|Tsar Nicholas I of Russia]] and [[Charlotte of Prussia]] * [[Mikheil Saakashvili]], former president of Georgia * [[Stepan Shahumyan]], politician * [[Eduard Shevardnadze]], former president of Georgia and [[Minister of Foreign Affairs]] of the Soviet Union * [[Joseph Stalin]], leader of the Soviet Union * [[Ekvtime Takaishvili]], politician and public benefactor * [[Giorgi Targamadze]], Georgia politician * [[Alimardan Topchubashev]], Azerbaijani politician * [[Sergei Witte]], important politician and policy-maker within the [[Russian Empire]] * [[Noe Zhordania]], Prime Minister of independent Georgia in 1918-1921 * [[Zurab Zhvania]], former [[prime minister]] of Georgia
==Writers== * [[Boris Akunin]], writer * [[Hovaness Toumanian]], poet and writer * [[Nikoloz Baratashvili]], poet and writer * [[Konstantine Gamsakhurdia]], one of the most influential Georgian writers of the 20th century * [[Maxim Gorky]], Soviet writer, founder of the [[socialist realism]] literary method {{citation needed|date=August 2012}} * [[Mirza Fatali Akhundov]], writer * [[Hakob Melik-Hakobyan (Raffi)]], writer * [[Ryurik Ivnev]], poet * [[Dagny Juel]], writer * [[Akaki Tsereteli]], writer * [[Lesya Ukrainka]], [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] poet * [[Friedrich Martin von Bodenstedt]], writer * [[Chabua Amirejibi]], writer
==Scientists, engineers, designers and inventors== * [[Malkhaz Abdushelishvili]], scientist ([[anthropologist]]) * [[Andria Apakidze]], scientist ([[archaeologist]]) * [[Viktor Amazaspovich Ambartsumian]], astronomer * [[Georgy Mikhailovich Beriev]], aircraft designer, founder of the [[Beriev|Beriev Design Bureau]] * [[Felix d'Herelle]], French-Canadian microbiologist, one of the discoverers of [[bacteriophages]] * [[Revaz Dogonadze]], [[physicist]] * [[Tamaz Gamkrelidze]], [[linguist]] * [[Joseph Jordania]], [[ethnomusicologist]], evolutionary musicologist * [[Alexander Kartveli]] (Kartvelishvili), aircraft engineer * [[Gustav Radde]], scientist * [[Alexander de Seversky]], aircraft engineer * [[Otto Wilhelm Hermann von Abich]], mineralogist and geologist
==Musicians, singers and composers== * [[Robert Bardzimashvili]], singer, founder of Orera, Via-75 * [[Rashid Behbudov]], singer * [[Feodor Chaliapin]], [[opera]] singer * [[Irakli Charkviani]], Georgian poet and rock/pop singer * [[Givi Gachechiladze]], composer, conductor, Tbilisi State Orchestra "Rero", The Mardzhanishvili Theater Orchestra, Tbilisi Municipal Concert Orchestra * [[Hamlet Gonashvili]], tenor * [[Alexander Melik-Pashayev]], Soviet conductor * [[Niyazi|Niyazi Hajibeyov]], conductor, composer * [[Mikhail Ippolitov-Ivanov]], composer * [[Giya Kancheli]], composer * [[Rudolf Kehrer]], pianist * [[Aram Khachaturian]], composer * [[Niaz Diasamidze]], Georgian composer and [[folk rock]] singer, founder of the band [[33a]] * [[Zakharia Paliashvili]], composer, founder of Georgian [[European classical music|classical music]] * [[Alexander Toradze]], pianist * [[Lev Vlassenko]], pianist * [[Paata Burchuladze]], operatic bass, civil activist and politician * [[Lisa Batiashvili]], violinist
==Theatre, cinema, arts and entertainment== * [[Tengiz Abuladze]], film director * [[Elene Akhvlediani]], painter * [[Nino Ananiashvili]], ballerina * [[Gela Babluani]], film director; directed the acclaimed film ''[[13 Tzameti]]'' * [[Temur Babluani]], film director * [[Ramaz Chkhikvadze]], theatre, cinema artist * [[Georgi Daneliya]], film director * [[Lado Gudiashvili]], painter * [[Otar Ioseliani]], film director * [[Vakhtang Kikabidze]], actor * [[Sergei Parajanov]], producer * [[Ia Parulava]] * [[Elena Satine]], actor, singer * [[Robert Sturua]], director * [[Eteri Tchkonia]], opera singer * [[Lamara Tchkonia]], opera singer * [[Natela Tchkonia]], opera singer * [[Georgy Tovstonogov]], [[Russia]]n theatre director * [[Avksenty Tsagareli]], playwright * [[Zurab Tsereteli]], artist, architect * [[Marie Vorobieff]], painter
==Sports figures== * [[Shota Arveladze]], [[soccer]] player * [[Maia Chiburdanidze]], former women's [[world chess champion]] * [[Vitali Daraselia]], former football (soccer) player for [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]] and the [[USSR national football team|Soviet Union National Team]] * [[Roman Dzindzichashvili]], chess grandmaster * [[Teymuraz Gabashvili]], tennis player * [[Nona Gaprindashvili]], former women's world chess champion * [[Elene Gedevanishvili]], [[figure skating|figure skater]] * [[Kakha Kaladze]], football (soccer) player for the [[Georgia national football team]] and [[AC Milan]] * [[David Kipiani]], former football (soccer) player for [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]] and the [[USSR national football team|Soviet Union National Team]] * [[Zaza Pachulia]], NBA player * [[Tigran Petrosian]], former world chess champion * [[Murtaz Shelia]], former football player for [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]] and [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] * [[Zurab Zviadauri]], judoka * [[Ilias Iliadis]], judoka
==Military figures== * [[Konstantine Abkhazi|Konstantine "Kote" Abkhazi]], general * [[Timur Apakidze]], general * [[Hovhannes Bagramyan]], military commander and [[Marshal]] of the Soviet Union * [[Aleksei Brusilov]], Russian cavalry general * [[Anatoli Gekker]], Soviet commander * [[Giorgi Kvinitadze]], founder of the Tbilisi [[Junker]] school * [[Mikhail Tarielovich Loris-Melikov]], general * [[Giorgi Mazniashvili]], general
==Other== * [[Mikael Aramyants]], businessman and philanthropist * [[Zurab Avalishvili]], historian * [[Arnold Chikobava]], linguist * [[Jeanne de Salzmann]], mystic * [[Pavel Florensky]], philosopher, theologian * [[Irene Galitzine]], fashion designer * [[Ivane Javakhishvili]], [[historian]], public benefactor * [[Alexander Mantashev]], prominent [[Armenia]]n oil magnate, industrialist, financier, and philanthropist * [[Tako Natsvlishvili]], fashion model
==Honorary citizens== People awarded the [[honorary citizenship]] of Tbilisi are:

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Politics of Taiwan}} This article lists '''[[political parties]] in [[Taiwan]]'''. == Current parties == === Parties with national or local representation === * '''National representation''' includes the [[President of the Republic of China|President]], the [[Vice President of the Republic of China|Vice President]], and the 113 national legislator seats in the [[Legislative Yuan]]. * '''Local representation''' includes the [[List of heads of governments of special municipalities, counties and cities in Taiwan|22 mayors/magistrates executive positions]] and 912 local legislator (councils) seats of the 6 [[Special municipality (Taiwan)|special municipalities]], 3 [[Provincial city (Taiwan)|cities]] and 13 [[County (Taiwan)|counties]]. {{clear}} {|class=wikitable !rowspan=3 colspan=2 width=320|Party !!colspan=3|Representation !!rowspan=3 width=120|Party Leader !!rowspan=3 width=100|Political
position !!rowspan=3 width=400|Notes |- !rowspan=2|National!! colspan="2" |Local |- !Leaders!!Councils |- |bgcolor={{Democratic Progressive Party/meta/color}}| |[[Democratic Progressive Party]]
{{lang|zh-tw|民主進步黨}} ''Mínzhǔ Jìnbù Dǎng''
''Bîn-chú Chìn-pō͘ Tóng'' |align=center|'''Ruling party'''
68||align=center|6||align=center|238 | [[Tsai Ing-wen]] | [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]] | [[Liberalism in Taiwan|Liberalism]], [[Progressivism]], [[Taiwanese nationalism]]. Leader of the [[Pan-Green Coalition]] in [[Taiwan]], also a member of [[Liberal International]]. |- |bgcolor={{Kuomintang/meta/color}}| |[[Kuomintang]]
{{lang|zh-tw|中國國民黨}} ''Zhōngguó Guómíndǎng''
''Tiong-kok Kok-bîn-tóng'' |align=center|35||align=center|15||align=center|394 | [[Wu Den-yih]] | [[Centre-right politics|Centre-right]] | [[Conservatism]], [[Chinese nationalism]], [[Three Principles of the People]]. Leader of the [[Pan-Blue Coalition]] in [[Taiwan]], also a member of [[International Democrat Union]] |- |bgcolor={{New Power Party/meta/color}}| |[[New Power Party]]
{{lang|zh-tw|時代力量}} ''Shídài Lìliàng''
''Sî‑tāi Le̍k‑liōng'' |align=center|5||align=center| — ||align=center| 16 | [[Huang Kuo-chang]] | [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]] | [[Progressivism]], [[Social liberalism]], [[Taiwanese nationalism]]. Considered a member of the [[Pan-Green Coalition]]. |- |bgcolor={{People First Party (Republic of China)/meta/color}}| |[[People First Party (Republic of China)|People First Party]]
{{lang|zh-tw|親民黨}} ''Qīnmín Dǎng''
''Chhin-bîn Tóng'' |align=center|3||align=center| — ||align=center| 8 | [[James Soong]] | [[Centre-right politics|Centre-right]] | [[Liberal conservatism]], [[Chinese nationalism]]. Considered a member of the [[Pan-Blue Coalition]], now functions more independently from [[Kuomintang]], sometimes refers to the Orange Group. |- |bgcolor={{Non-Partisan Solidarity Union/meta/color}}| |[[Non-Partisan Solidarity Union]]
{{lang|zh-tw|無黨團結聯盟}} ''Wúdǎng Tuánjié Liánméng''
''Bû-tóng Thoân-kiat Liân-bêng'' |align=center|1||align=center| — ||align=center| 5 | [[:zh:林炳坤|Lin Ping-kun]] | [[Centre-right politics|Centre-right]] | [[Conservative liberalism]]. Considered a member of the [[Pan-Blue Coalition]]. |- |bgcolor={{Taiwan Solidarity Union/meta/color}}| |[[Taiwan Solidarity Union]]
{{lang|zh-tw|台灣團結聯盟}} ''Táiwān Tuánjié Liánméng''
''Tâi-oân Thoân-kiat Liân-bêng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| 5 | [[Liu Yi-te]] | [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]] | [[Progressivism]], [[Social liberalism]], [[Taiwanese nationalism]], [[Taiwan independence]]. A member of [[Pan-Green Coalition]]. |- |bgcolor=00FF00| ||[[Green Party Taiwan]]
{{lang|zh-tw|台灣綠黨}} ''Táiwān Lǜ Dǎng''
''Tâi-ôan Le̍k Tóng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| 3 | [[Lee Keng-cheng]]
[[Chang Yu-jing]] | [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]] | [[Green politics]]. A member of the Social Welfare National Alliance in [[Taiwan]], also a member of [[Global Greens]]. |- |bgcolor=FFDB00| ||[[Minkuotang]]
{{lang|zh-tw|民國黨}} ''Mínguó Dǎng''
''Bîn-kok Tóng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| 3 | [[Hsu Hsin-Ying]] | [[Centre-right politics|Centre-right]] | [[Liberal conservatism]], [[Three Principles of the People]]. Considered a member of the [[Pan-Blue Coalition]], closer to the Orange Groups. |- |bgcolor=D60E29| |[[Labor Party (Taiwan)|Labor Party]]
{{lang|zh-tw|勞動黨}} ''Láodòng Dǎng''
''Lô-tōng Tóng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| 2 | [[Wu Rong-yuan]] | [[Far-left politics|Far-left]] | [[Communism]], [[Chinese nationalism]], [[Chinese Reunification]]. Unaligned to any political coalitions in [[Taiwan]], a member of [[International Communist Seminar]] |- |bgcolor={{New Party (Republic of China)/meta/color}}| |[[New Party (Republic of China)|New Party]]

{{lang|zh-tw|中華民族致公黨}} ''Zhōnghuá Mínzú Zhìgōng Dǎng''
''Tiong-hôa Bîn-cho̍k Tì-kong Tóng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| 1 | [[Tsai Chun-sheng]] | [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] | [[Chinese nationalism]], [[Chinese Reunification]]. Unaligned to any political coalitions in [[Taiwan]]. |- |bgcolor=E6267C| |[[Social Democratic Party (Taiwan)|Social Democratic Party]]
{{lang|zh-tw|社會民主黨}} ''Shèhuì Mínzhǔ Dǎng''
''Siā-hōe Bîn-chú Tóng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| 1 | [[Fan Yun]] | [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]] | [[Social democracy]]. A member of the Social Welfare National Alliance in [[Taiwan]]. |- |bgcolor=C69E6A| ||[[Taiwan First Nations Party]]
{{lang|zh-tw|台灣第一民族黨}} ''Táiwān Dìyī Mínzú Dǎng''
''Tâi-oân Tē-it Bîn-cho̍k Tóng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| 1 | [[Shih Ching-lung]] | [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]] | [[Taiwanese aborigines|Taiwanese aboriginal]] nationalism. Unaligned to any political coalitions in [[Taiwan]]. |- |bgcolor=73BF00| ||[[Trees Party]]
{{lang|zh-tw|樹黨}} ''Shù Dǎng''
''Chhiū Tóng'' |align=center| — ||align=center| — ||align=center| — | [[Pan Han-chiang]]
[[Lin Chia-yu]] | [[Centre-left politics|Centre-left]] | [[Environmentalism]]. Party]] (中國青蓮黨) ||15 March 2011||[[He Junyuan]] (何俊元) |- |184|| [[Chinese Culture Party]] (中華文化黨)||17 March 2012||[[Lin Zhongshan]] (林忠山) |- |185|| [[New Power Party]] (時代力量)||25 January 2015||[[Huang Kuo-chang]] (黃國昌) |} {{hidden end}} == Historical parties == === Taiwan under Japanese rule === {{main|Taiwan under Japanese rule|Political parties of the Empire of Japan}} Political party movements in [[Taiwan]] started in the late 1910s after World War I, during the [[Taishō period]] (Taishō Democracy). Taiwanese political movements at this time were to modify the discriminatory colonial laws established in earlier years, and to setup local autonomy systems like in [[Mainland Japan]]. The largest political movement at this time was the [[Petition Movement for the Establishment of a Taiwanese Parliament]]. At the same time, the [[History of communism|International Communist Movement]] also influenced [[Taiwan]], many [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] parties and organizations were also established. Notable Taiwanese parties during this time are: * [[Taiwan Dōkakai]] ({{lang|zh-tw|臺灣同化會}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tâi-oân Tông-hòa-hōe'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taiwan Dōkakai'') * [[New People Society]] ({{lang|zh-tw|新民會}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Sin-bîn-hōe'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Shinminkai'') * [[Taiwanese Cultural Association]] ({{lang|zh-tw|臺灣文化協會}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tâi-oân Bûn-hòa Hia̍p-hōe'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taiwan Bunka Kyōkai'') * [[Taiwanese Federation of Workers' Unions]] ({{lang|zh-tw|臺灣工友總聯盟}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tâi-oân Kang-iú Chóng Liân-bêng'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taiwan Kōyū Sōrenmei'') * [[Taiwanese Peasants Union]] ({{lang|zh-tw|臺灣農民組合}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tâi-oân Lông-bîn Cho͘-ha̍p'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taiwan Nōmin Kumiai'') * [[Taiwanese Communist Party]] ({{lang|zh-tw|臺灣共產黨}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tâi-oân Kiōng-sán Tóng'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taiwan Kyōsan-tō'') * [[Taiwanese People's Party]] ({{lang|zh-tw|臺灣民眾黨}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tâi-oân Bîn-chiòng Tóng'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taiwan Minshu-tō'') * [[Taiwan Local Autonomy Union]] ({{lang|zh-tw|臺灣地方自治聯盟}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tâi-oân Tē-hng Chū-tī Liân-bêng'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taiwan Tihō-jiti Renmei'') At the same time, the political parties in [[Mainland Japan]] also affected Taiwan. Most of the [[Governor-General of Taiwan]] were also members of the [[House of Peers (Japan)|House of Peers]] of the [[National_Diet#History|Imperial Diet]] ({{lang|ja|帝国議会}}). Party affiliations of the Governor-Generals were: * [[Rikken Seiyūkai]] ({{lang|ja|立憲政友会}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Li̍p-hiàn Chèng-iú-hōe'') * [[Kenseikai]] ({{lang|ja|憲政会}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Hiàn-chèng-hōe'') * [[Rikken Minseitō]] ({{lang|ja|立憲民政党}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Li̍p-hiàn Bîn-chèng Tóng'') However, in the late 1930s, the [[Empire of Japan]] joins the [[World War II]]. To prepare for the [[Pacific War]], all political parties in [[Mainland Japan]] were forced to be merged into a single organization * [[Imperial Rule Assistance Association]] ({{lang|ja|大政翼贊會}}, [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Taisei Yokusankai'', [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tāi-chèng-i̍k-chàn-hōe'') with its Taiwanese branch * [[Kōmin Hōkōkai]] ({{lang|ja|皇民奉公會}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Hông-bîn Hōng-kong-hōe'', [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]: ''Kōmin Hōkōkai'') was the only legal political party-like organization in [[Taiwan]] until the end of [[World War II]]. === Taiwan after World War II === {{see also|History of Taiwan since 1945}} [[Taiwan]] was ceded back to the [[Republic of China (1912–49)|Republic of China]], founded in [[Xinhai Revolution|1912]] on the [[Mainland China|mainland]], on [[Retrocession Day|25 October 1945]] and was placed under [[Martial law in Taiwan|martial law]] from 19 May 1949 to 15 July 1987. At this time, all forms of [[Opposition (politics)|opposition]] were forbidden by the government, only three political parties who retreated to [[Taiwan]] were allowed to participate the elections. * [[Kuomintang]] ({{lang|zh-tw|中國國民黨}}, [[Standard Chinese|Chinese]]: ''Zhōngguó Guómíndǎng'', [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tiong-kok Kok-bîn-tóng''){{efn|KMT's prior body was [[Revive China Society]] (Xinzhonghui 興中會), founded on 24 November 1894. It officially renamed itself as China Nationalist Party 中國國民黨 in 1919.}} * [[Chinese Youth Party]] ({{lang|zh-tw|中國青年黨}}, [[Standard Chinese|Chinese]]: ''Zhōngguó Qīngniándǎng'', [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tiong-kok Chheng-liân-tóng'') * [[China Democratic Socialist Party]] ({{lang|zh-tw|中國民主社會黨}}, [[Standard Chinese|Chinese]]: ''Zhōngguó Mínzhǔ Shèhuìdǎng'', [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Tiong-kok Bîn-chú Siā-hoē-tóng''){{efn|The prior body of China Democratic Socialist Party (中國民主社會黨) was China National Socialist Party (中國國家社會黨), which was founded on 16 April 1932. It renamed itself as China Democratic Socialist Party (中國民主社會黨) on 15 August 1946.}} All other oppositions who were not allowed not form a political party could only be listed as "independent candidate". These movements were called [[Tangwai movement]] ({{lang|zh-tw|黨外}}, literally ''outside of Kuomintang''). A notable exception in this era was * [[Democratic Progressive Party]] ({{lang|zh-tw|民主進步黨}}, [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]: ''Bîn-chú Chìn-pō͘ Tóng'', [[Standard Chinese|Chinese]]: ''Mínzhǔ Jìnbù Dǎng''). It was established "illegally" in 28 September 1986, then was legalized in the next year by the lift of the martial law. === Democratization === As [[Taiwan]] democratized in the late 1980s, the number of legally registered political parties in [[Taiwan]] had increased exponentially and continued to increase year by year, indicating a liberal democracy and high political freedom in [[Taiwan]]. {| class=wikitable |+ Number of registered political parties by year |-align=center ! Year | 1990 || 1992 || 1994 || 1996 || 1998 || 2000 || 2002 || 2004 || 2006 || 2008 || 2010 || 2012 || 2014 || 2016 |-align=center !No. parties | 60 || 72 || 75 || 82 || 87 || 94 || 99 || 110 || 122 || 145 || 177 || 234 || 264 || 310 |} In the recent decades, [[Taiwan]]'s political campaigns can be classified to two ideological blocs * The [[Pan-Green Coalition]], led by [[Democratic Progressive Party]], favors [[Taiwanization]] and the [[Taiwan independence movement]], eventually aiming to establish a Taiwanese [[sovereign state]]. * The [[Pan-Blue Coalition]], led by [[Kuomintang]], is in favor of building closer ties with [[China]] and the eventual [[Chinese unification]] under the [[Government of the Republic of China]]. The majority in both coalitions state a desire to maintain the status quo for now. Many minor parties in Taiwan are unaligned with either coalition. ==See also== {{Portal|Taiwan|Politics}} * [[Conservatism in Taiwan]] * [[February 28 Incident]] * [[History of Taiwan]] * [[Economic history of Taiwan]] * [[Politics of the Republic of China]] * [[Political parties of the Empire of Japan]] * [[History of political parties in China]] * [[List of political parties by country]] * [[List of rulers of Taiwan]] * [[Elections in Taiwan]] ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.moi.gov.tw/ Ministry of the Interior] * [http://www.moi.gov.tw/dca/02people_005-1.aspx?sn=10 List of Political Parties] * [http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3103356 Document unearthed shows double-dealing of Chiang behind 228 Incident - Taiwan News] {{Taiwanese political parties}} {{Asia topic|List of political parties in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Political Parties In Taiwan}} [[Category:Political parties in Taiwan| ]] [[Category:Lists of political parties by country|Taiwan]] [[Category:Taiwan politics-related lists|Political parties]] [[Category:Politics of the Republic of China]] [[Category:Taiwan-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of political parties in Asia|Taiwan]]

{{Politics of Spain}} This article lists '''political parties in the [[Canary Islands]]'''.
==The parties== <!--''The general rule on naming applies. That means: the parties are named in the English translation and the original native name is placed on the first line of the article unless the native form is more commonly used in English than the English form. Rationale and specifics: See: [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (use English)]]''.--> Most of the [[List of political parties in Spain|Spanish political parties]] are active in the Canary Islands. In addition are the following regional parties:
*[[Alternativa Popular Canaria|People's Alternative for the Canary Islands]] (''Alternativa Popular Canaria'') *[[Azarug]] *[[Canarian Assembly]] (''Asamblea Canaria'') *[[Canarian Coalition]] (''Coalición Canaria'') *[[Canary Islands Independence Movement]] (''Movimiento por la Autodeterminación e Independencia del Archipiélago Canario'') *[[Canarian Nationalist Alternative]] (''Alternativa Nacionalista Canaria'') *[[Canarian Nationalist Party]] *[[Canarian People's Union]] (''Unión del Pueblo Canario'') *[[Canarian United Left]] *[[Communist Cells]] (''Células Comunistas'') *[[Communist Party of the Canaries]] (''Partido Comunista de Canarias'') *[[Democratic Arucasian Union]] (''Unión Aruquense Democrática'') *[[Inekaren]] (''Organización Revolucionaria de Jóvenes Canarios Los Alzados'') *[[National Congress of the Canaries]] (''Congreso Nacional de Canarias'') *[[New Canarias]] (''Nueva Canarias'') *[[Party of Communist Unification in the Canaries]] (''Partido de Unificación Comunista en Canarias'') *[[Popular Front of the Canary Islands]] (''Frente Popular de las Islas Canarias'') *[[Socialist Canarian Party]] (''Partido Canario Socialista'') *[[Unidad del Pueblo|Unity of the People]] (''Unidad del Pueblo'')
==See also== * [[List of political parties by country]]

page.title: List of postal codes in Germany

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=April 2018}}
[[File:German postcode information.png|thumb|350px|German Postleitzahl map of the first two digits. The green lines mark state borders which do not correspond with postal code areas.]] '''Postal codes in Germany''', ''Postleitzahl'' (plural Postleitzahlen, abbreviated to PLZ; literally "postal routing number"), since 1 July 1993 consist of five digits. The first two digits indicate the wider area, the last three digits the postal district.
Before reunification, both the [[West Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]] (FRG) and the [[German Democratic Republic]] (GDR) used four-digit [[postal code|codes]]. Under a transitional arrangement following reunification, between 1989 and 1993 postal codes in the west were prefixed with 'W', e.g.: '''W-1000 [Berlin] 30''' (postal districts in western cities were separate from the postal code) and those in the east with 'O' (for ''Ost''), e.g.: '''O-1xxx Berlin'''.
City administrations and postal customers with high mail volumes, or ''Großkunden'' have their own postal codes, separate from those used for postal districts or PO Box number ranges.
Postal regions do not necessarily follow [[States of Germany|state]] boundaries, so sorting by state is not practical.
The postal regions and some postal codes are: {{TOC right}}
== 5-digit System since 1993 ==
The 5-digit postal codes were established on July 1, 1993.

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
The '''Milthorpe Lecture''' is a series of [[public lecture]]s on environmental science held at [[Macquarie University]], [[Australia]]. It is endowed by the [[Milthorpe Fund]] in memory of [[F.L. Milthorpe]], Chair of Biology at the University from 1967–1982. The first lecture was delivered by [[David Suzuki]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mq.edu.au/staffnews/archive/06/stafnews9.html |title=Dr Clive Hamilton to deliver 2006 Milthorpe Lecture on The political economy of climate change |accessdate=2013-10-08 |work=Macquarie University Marketing Unit }}</ref>
== List of lecturers == * Dr. [[David Suzuki]], Biologist and Environmental Activist (1989) * Professor [[Paul R. Ehrlich]], Biologist * Sir [[Ninian Stephen]], Former [[Governor-General of Australia]] and Australian Ambassador for the Environment (1990) * [[Neville Wran]], Former [[Premier of New South Wales]] and Chairman of the [[Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation]] (1991) * Senator Dr. [[Bob Brown]], Environmental Activist and Australian Senator * Professor [[Mike Archer (Paleontologist)|Michael Archer]], Director of the [[Australian Museum]] * Senator [[John Faulkner]], Australian Senator and [[Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts (Australia)|Minister for the Environment]] (1995)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22media%2Fpressrel%2FFTK20%22 |title=Ecologically sustainable development: from theory to practice |date=1995-11-02 |accessdate=2016-11-23 |work=Press releases database, Australian Parliamentary Library }}</ref> * Dr. [[Richard Anthony Jefferson|Richard Jefferson]], Biologist and CEO of [[CAMBIA]] (1999)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bioline.org.br/request?au99013 |title=The Future of Genetically Engineered Food Crops |accessdate=2009-07-20 |format= |work=Editorial, Australasian Biotechnology Volume 9 Number 5, November/December 1999 }}</ref> * Dr. [[Clive Hamilton]], Executive Director of [[The Australia Institute]] (2006) <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clivehamilton.net.au/cms/media/documents/articles/The_Political_Economy_of_Climate_Change.pdf |title=The Political Economy of Climate Change |accessdate=2009-07-20 |format= |work=Clive Hamilton |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913104056/http://www.clivehamilton.net.au/cms/media/documents/articles/The_Political_Economy_of_Climate_Change.pdf |archivedate=2009-09-13 |df= }}</ref> * Professor [[Peter Singer]], Bioethicist (2009)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mq.edu.au/newsroom/2009/06/30/climate-change-eating-meat-and-ending-poverty-peter-singer-to-give-public-lecture/ |title=Climate change, eating meat and ending poverty: Peter Singer to give public lecture |accessdate=2013-10-08 |format= |work=Macquarie University Marketing Unit |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008102402/http://www.mq.edu.au/newsroom/2009/06/30/climate-change-eating-meat-and-ending-poverty-peter-singer-to-give-public-lecture/ |archivedate=2013-10-08 |df= }}</ref> * Professor [[Ian Chubb]], [[Office of the Chief Scientist (Australia)|Chief Scientist]] of Australia (2013)<ref>{{cite web Environmental and Science Journalist (2014)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bio.mq.edu.au/news/milthorpe-public-lecture-welcome/|title=Milthorpe Public Lecture|accessdate=2014-02-23 |work=Macquarie University Department of Biological Sciences}}</ref>

{{Administrative divisions of Mongolia}} [[Image:Ulan Bator subdivisions.png|right|thumb|320px| Düürgüüd of Ulaanbaatar]] A '''düüreg''' ({{lang-mn|дүүрэг}}) is a municipal district in the capital of [[Mongolia]], [[Ulaanbaatar]]. Each of the nine düürgüüd is subdivided into [[khoroo]]s. Each düüreg also serves as a constituency that elects one or more representatives into the [[State Great Khural]], the national parliament. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ The Düüregs of UlaanbaatarStatistics office of the city of Ulan Bator,[http://statis.ub.gov.mn/index2.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=235&Itemid=99999999] [http://www.statis.ub.gov.mn/Download/tan/2007/stat2701.pdf stat2701.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110074017/http://www.statis.ub.gov.mn/Download/tan/2007/stat2701.pdf |date=2007-11-10 }} [http://statis.ub.gov.mn/Download/Research/pop2006.01.01.pdf pop2006.01.01.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070222085701/http://statis.ub.gov.mn/Download/Research/pop2006.01.01.pdf |date=2007-02-22 }} |- ! Bagakhangai and Baganuur are noncontiguous exclaves, the former located within the [[Töv Province]], the latter on the border between the Töv and [[Khentii Province|Khentii]] provinces. == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Duureg}} [[Category:Districts of Ulaanbaatar| ]] [[Category:Types of country subdivisions]]

'''Okres''' ([[Czech language|Czech]] and [[Slovak language|Slovak]] term meaning "district" in [[English language|English]]; from German Kreis - circle (or perimeter)) refers to administrative entities in the [[Czech Republic]] and [[Slovakia]]. It is similar to Landkreis in Germany or Okrug in Slavic speaking countries.
The first districts in the Czech lands developed from domains in 1850 by the decision of the Imperial government of [[Austrian Empire|Austria]]. In the territory of present day Slovakia their predecessors were districts of the [[counties of the Kingdom of Hungary]] ''(slúžnovský okres'' in Slovak). The organisation and functions of the districts were different in the Czech lands and Hungary. After the creation of [[Czechoslovakia]] districts became an administrative unit of the new state with a unified status. After the [[dissolution of Czechoslovakia]] in 1993, the district system was taken over by the two current successor states.
==Equivalents== *[[Okręg]] *[[Okrug]] *[[Okruhas of Ukraine|Okruha]]
==See also== * [[Districts of Slovakia]] (okres) * [[Districts of the Czech Republic]] (okres) * [[Powiat]] * [[Raion]]
===Upper-level division=== * [[Krai]] * [[Districts of Germany|Kreis]] * [[Regions of Slovakia]] ([[kraj]]) * [[Regions of the Czech Republic]] (kraj)
===Lower-level division=== * [[Obec]] (subdivisions of an okres)
==External links== * [http://www.czso.cz/lexikon/mos2003.nsf/index Map: location of every ''okres'' in the Czech Republic]
{{Slavic terms for country subdivisions}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Okres}}
{{geo-term-stub}}

revision.text:
{{other people|Peter Taylor}} '''Peter James Taylor''', [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]], [[FAcSS]] (born 21 November 1944) is an [[English People|English]] [[geography|geographer]]. Born in [[Calverton, Nottinghamshire|Calverton]] in [[Nottinghamshire]], he was Professor of Political Geography at the [[University of Newcastle upon Tyne]] between 1970 and 1996, before joining [[Loughborough University]] as Professor of Geography<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/t/23884/Peter+TAYLOR.aspx|title=Prof Peter Taylor|accessdate=2010-10-10|work=Debrett's People of Today}}</ref> Since 2010 he was worked at [[Northumbria University]]. He is the co-founding editor of the journal Political Geography, and is the founder and Director of the [[Globalization and World Cities Research Network]] and is the author of over 300 publications, of which over 60 have been translated into other languages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackwell-compass.com/subject/geography/article_biog?article_id=geco_articles_bpl216|title=Peter J. Taylor, Ben Derudder, Cándida Gago García and Frank Witlox - Short Biographies|accessdate=2010-10-10|work=Geography Compass|publisher=Blackwell publishing}}</ref> In September 2010 he became a Professor of Geography at [[Northumbria University]].
Tn 2004, Taylor was elected a Fellow of the [[British Academy]] (FBA), the United Kingdom's [[national academy]].<ref>[https://www.britac.ac.uk/users/professor-peter-taylor "Professor Peter Taylor"], ''[[British Academy]]''. Retrieved 5 June 2018.</ref>
==Publications==
* ''International Handbook of Globalization and World Cities'' (2011) * ''Political Geography: World-Economy, Nation-State, Locality'' (2011) * ''Global Urban Analysis: a Survey of Cities in Globalization'' (2010) * ''Cities in Globalization'' (2006) * ''World City Network: a Global Urban Analysis'' (2004) * ''Modernities: a Geohistorical Introduction'' (1999) * ''The Way the Modern World Works: from World Hegemony to World Impasse'' (1996)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.lboro.ac.uk/departments/gy/staff/gypjt/index.html Professor Peter Taylor], homepage at Department of Geography, Loughborough University * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110822033427/http://www.northumbria.ac.uk/sd/academic/sobe/divisions/geogenv/geogstaff/peter_taylor/ Professor Peter J Taylor], homepage at Department of Geography and Environment, Northumbria University

Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "The movement of an ocean current that doubles back on itself" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|The movement of an ocean current that doubles back on itself}} '''Retroflection''' is the movement of an ocean current that doubles back on itself.
==Usage history== More commonly used to describe the way the mammalian [[intestine]] or [[uterus]] might turn back on itself, retroflection was first used in an oceanographic sense in 1970 by South African oceanographer [[Nils Bang]], to describe the [[Agulhas Current]]<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Lutjeharms | first = J. R. E. | title = Three decades of research on the greater Agulhas Current | year = 2006 | journal = Ocean Sci. Discuss. | volume = 3 | pages = 939–995 | oclc = 800498605}}</ref> which curves on itself at the southern tip of Africa to become the Aghulhas Return Current.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Bang | first = N. D. | title = Dynamic interpretations of a detailed surface temperature chart of the Agulhas Current retroflection and fragmentation area | year = 1970 | journal = South African Geographical Journal | volume = 52 | pages = 67–76 | doi = 10.1080/03736245.1970.10559466}}</ref> Bang credited the inspiration for the metaphor to his wife, Alison Coombe Bang, a nursing sister, who mentioned the term during her midwifery studies. Bang's research, through the University of Cape Town, was done on a limited budget and with rudimentary equipment,<ref name="SDB-1977">Sciendaba, Vol XII No 48, 15 December 1977</ref> yet his studies using closely spaced [[bathythermograph]] readings, were later corroborated by satellite thermal imagery. The term was then revived<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Lutjeharms | first = J. R. E | title = Features of the southern Agulhas Current circulation from satellite remote sensing | year = 1981 | journal = South African Journal of Science | volume = 77 | pages = 231–236}}</ref> and is now common parlance among oceanographers. The Agulhas current's retroflection is now key to an understanding of its dynamics.<ref name="SDB-1977" />
==Retroflection regions== The [[North Brazil Current]] (NBC) is a western [[boundary current]] that flows off the coast of northeast Brazil, in the tropical Atlantic that transports upper ocean waters across the equator. It retroflects between 4°N and 10°N. Particularly during summer and fall, the NBC retroflects from the coast at 6° to 7°N and feeds the [[Equatorial Counter Current|North Equatorial Countercurrent]] and [[Equatorial Undercurrent|North Equatorial Undercurrent]]. The NBC sheds large anticyclonic rings that move northwestward along the [[continental break]]. (Didden and Schott, 1993). These warm rings could play an important role in the net meridional transport of warm water in the upper layers of the Atlantic Ocean as part of the [[meridional overturning circulation]] (MOC).<ref name=NBC-1> {{Include-NOAA}} *{{Cite web | title =Long Term Time Series of Surface Currents, North Brazil Current | publisher =NOAA-AOML | date =June 8, 2007 | url =http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/phod/altimetry/cvar/nbc/index.php | format =Online (website) | accessdate =2011-05-28}} </ref><ref name=NBC-2> {{Include-NOAA}} *{{Cite web | title =North Brazil Current | publisher =NOAA-AOML | url =http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/phod/benchmarks/North%20Brazil%20Current/NBC%20Sept.html | format =Online (website) | accessdate =2011-05-28}}</ref>
In the southeast [[Atlantic Ocean]] the current ''retroflects'' (turns back on itself) in the Agulhas Retroflection due to shear interactions with the strong [[Antarctic Circumpolar Current]]. This water becomes the [[Agulhas Return Current]], rejoining the [[Indian Ocean Gyre]]. It is estimated that up to 85 Sv ([[Sverdrup]]s) of the net transport is returned to the [[Indian Ocean]] through the retroflection. The remaining water is transported into the [[South Atlantic Gyre]] in the Agulhas Leakage. Along with direct branch currents, this leakage takes place in surface water filaments, and Agulhas Eddies.<ref>This paragraph is copied from the section entitled ''Retroflection'' in the Wikipedia article entitled [[Agulhas Current]]. This for attribution only and it is not considered a reliable source.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Oceans]] [[Category:Ocean currents]] [[Category:Wikipedia articles incorporating text from NOAA]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} [[Image:Rivinletto Light.jpg|thumb|260px|[[Rivinletto Light]] on Kaasanmatala rock at the mouth of [[Kiiminkijoki]] in [[Haukipudas]], [[Finland]] is a typical sector light beacon.]][[Image:Leitfeuer_001.svg|thumb|Example of a sector light. The ship is navigating in the safe sector (white light is commonly marked as yellow in nautical charts).]]
A '''sector light''' is a man-made [[pilotage]] and [[position fixing]] aid that consists of strictly de-limited horizontal angle light beams to guide water-borne traffic through a safe channel at night in reasonable visibility. Sector lights are most often used for safe passage through shallow or dangerous waters. This may be when leaving or entering harbour. Nautical charts (paper and electronic) give all the required information.
Sectors of colored glass (or plastic) are placed in the lanterns of these lights. The light will then show these colors when observed certain bearings. Bearings referring to a sector are given in degrees true as observed from sea. Though the colors of the light will change, the characteristics will not. The change of color is not abrupt. The transition is made through an arc of uncertainty of 2° or greater.
The colors that are used, are conform to the IALA Maritime Bouyage system that is designed by the [[International Association of Lighthouse Authorities]]: * white - this sector is in the middle of the safe channel * red - indicates the [[port (nautical)|port]] edge of the channel for vessels approaching the light source * green - indicates the [[starboard]] edge of the channel for vessels approaching the light source. A ship that is sailing in safe water and then sees the red (or green) color of the light has to make an alteration in course.
The world has different navigation stereotypes managed by IALA (International Association of Lighthouse Authorities). For example, the United States uses a signalling stereotype which is the opposite of Europe. In USA, the red light indicates the starboard side of the channel for harbour bound vessels, while the green light indicates the port side of the same channel. An expression to remind of this is "red right returning". [[File:Diego Garcia PEL.jpg|thumb|Diego Garcia PEL Sector Light. 3.5 million candela which is visible for over 18.5km by day. Total beam width of 1.6° with white sector of 0.2°.]]
== Example of a sector light == An example of a sector light is the light of the [[Fisgard Lighthouse National Historic Site|Fisgard Lighthouse]] in [[British Columbia]]. The lighthouse as built to guide ships through the entrance of Esquimalt harbour. The white sector is an isophase light of 2s from 322° to 195°. If the ship sees this white light, it can pass safely. The rest shows a red light from 195 to 322°. If a vessel sees this light, it should alter its course.
Another example is the [[PEL sector light]] at [[Diego Garcia]]. The PEL sector light was constructed to guide US Navy vessels into the Diego Garcia port through a narrow entrance in the lagoon.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.msc.navy.mil/sealift/2003/March/diegogarcia.htm|title = US Navy Military Sealift Command|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The PEL sector light produces 3.5 million candela and is visible for 10 nautical miles (18.5 km) by day. The beam with 3 colors is narrow at 1.6°.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://vega.co.nz/price-list/gallery/case-study-diego-garcia/|title = PEL-6 Diego Garcia|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> This was required because the PEL sector light was built over 7NM (13 km) from the atoll entrance and it had to illuminate a safe entrance which is only 228 meters wide.
==References== {{Commons category|Sector lights}} {{reflist}}
{{Lighthouses}}
[[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Lighthouses]]

{{refimprove|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = SuperMap | logo = SuperMapLogo.jpg | type = Public | key_people = Zhong Ershun, Founder/Chairman; Song Guanfu, Founder/President | industry = [[Software]]
[[Geographic information system|Geographic Information Systems (GIS)]] | products = SuperMap GIS, SuperMap iDesktop, SuperMap iObjects, SuperMap iServer, SuperMap iMobile, SuperMap iClient | revenue = 50 million USD year 2014 | num_employees = 2,000 (China) | homepage = {{URL|http://www.supermap.com}} | foundation = [[Beijing]], [[China PR]] (1997) }} '''SuperMap''' is a [[Geographic Information System]] (GIS) software products and services provider and IT enterprise in Asia. The headquarters are in [[Beijing]], [[China]]. The company was founded in 1997. It has over 20 branch offices in China and one office in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. SuperMap has developed lots of agencies and partners all over the world including South Korea, Malaysia, etc. There are more than 2,000 employees working in SuperMap as of 1 July 2016. In 2009, SuperMap was listed in [[Shenzhen Stock Exchange]] of [[China]] (300036.SZ). In 2014 revenues were about $50 million.{{Cite web|url=http://data.eastmoney.com/notice/20150331/2Wvl2W5uH9wUv8.html|title=SuperMap Revenues Report in 2014 (In Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=data.eastmoney.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-09}} In 2015, SuperMap occupied 31.6% of Chinese GIS market share, listed as number 1 of Chinese market share.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ccidnet.com/2016/0926/10188106.shtml|title=Chinese GIS Market in 2015 (In Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=ccidnet.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} ==Introduction== SuperMap was founded in 1997 under the support from [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]], SuperMap is headquartered in Beijing, China, and has established companies in Hong Kong and Tokyo for international business development. SuperMap has developed agencies and partners all over the world including South Korea, Malaysia, etc. SuperMap develops and provides GIS platforms and solutions for Smart City, Land Management, Environmental Protection, Public Service, Statistics GIS, Real Estate, Facility Management and Urban Management, etc. SuperMap applies a variety of information technologies to improve geospatial implementation in GIS and IT applications. SuperMap GIS is widely used in various fields.{{Cite web|url=http://www.supermap.com/en/html/Company.html|title=SuperMap GIS Software|website=www.supermap.com|access-date=2016-10-09}} == SuperMap GIS == SuperMap GIS is developed by SuperMap Software Co., Ltd and it is a complete integration of a series of GIS platform software, including Desktop GIS, Service GIS, Component GIS and Mobile GIS platforms and spatial data production, processing and management tools. Through continuous technological innovation, market exploring and experiences accumulation, SuperMap GIS has constructed a good GIS software brand with full angle, and strong functions which can meet different requirements for a wide range of industries, The main product series now are SuperMap 8C series products and SuperMap 7C series products.{{Cite web|url=http://www.supermap.com/en/html/products9.html|title=SuperMap GIS 8C_SuperMap GIS Software|website=www.supermap.com|access-date=2016-10-09}} == History == 1997: SuperMap was founded 2000: SuperMap Japan was founded 2000: Large-scale Component GIS Platform – SuperMap GIS 2000 was released 2005: The first cross-platform GIS Software in the world – SuperMap Universal GIS was released 2006: SuperMap International was founded in Hong Kong 2008: The National Sales and Service Network was established 2009: Listed in Shenzhen Stock Exchange 2009: The first 2D & 3D integration GIS platform – SuperMap GIS 6R was released 2013: Cloud & terminal integration platform – SuperMap GIS 7C was released 2014: Awarded top 10 enterprise of GIS industry in China 2015: Upgraded cloud & terminal GIS platform – SuperMap GIS 8C was released 2015: Full acquisition of Shanghai NanKang Technology Co., Ltd. 2016: Full acquisition of Nanjing Guotu Information Industry Co., Ltd. and Beijing Antu I2m Corporation Ltd.{{Cite web|url=http://www.supermap.com/en/html/history.html|title=SuperMap GIS Software|website=www.supermap.com|access-date=2016-10-13}} 2017: Expand International Business, representative office in Indonesia. 2017: Release new version, cloud and terminal integration, new 3D Generation and BIG DATA GIS, SuperMap 9D == Acquisitions == In order to have broaden the markets of the real estate registration, SuperMap has acquired Shanghai Nankang Technology Co.,Ltd.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gisempire.com/n/news/2015/1109/1749.html|title=SuperMap Acquires Nakang Technology (In Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=gisempire.com|access-date=2016-10-09}} in 2015, Nanjing Guotu Information Industry Co., Ltd.{{Cite web|url=http://finance.ifeng.com/a/20160104/14148173_0.shtml|title=SuperMap Aquires Nanjing Guotu (In Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=ifeng.com|access-date=2016-10-09}} and Beijing Antu I2M Corporation Ltd.{{Cite web|url=http://www.3snews.net/domestic/244000042369.html|title=SuperMap Acquires Antu I2M Corporation (in Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=3snews.net|access-date=2016-10-09}} in 2016. == Controversies == In 2016, the newly acquired company Beijing Antu I2m Corporation has won a bid with a much lower price than the usual market price, which then has raised controversies and discussions among the companies in GIS industry in China. Very soon after this bidding happened, the general manager of the Beijing Antu I2m Corporation has apologized to management teams of the competing GIS companies, saying that this is the only way to make the whole program deliver, and due to this action, the program has finalized smoothly. He also emphasized that Beijing Antu I2m Corporation has firmly objected low-cost competition and has never done this before and this would never happen again. When this bidding happened, the procedures of transferring the assets of the Beijing Antu I2m Corporation to SuperMap haven’t finished, Antu I2m still made biding on its own. But the management team of SuperMap took this seriously and issued the public letter to its users and companies of GIS industry, expressing that they are determined to eliminate the situations of ‘low cost’ biding and maintain the fairness and Prosperity of GIS market.{{Cite web|url=http://www.3snews.net/domestic/244000043511.html|title=Low Cost Bidding Raised Controversies In Chinese GIS Market (In Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=3snews.net|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:SuperMap}} [[Category:Companies of China]] [[Category:Geographic information systems]] [[Category:Earth sciences data formats]] [[Category:Companies based in Beijing]] [[Category:Companies established in 1997]] [[Category:Chinese brands]]
